  • Cryptocurrency Companies in Singapore Struggling due to Banking Freeze

Cryptocurrency Companies in Singapore Struggling due to Banking Freeze

There have been recent reports stating that bank accounts involved in the cryptocurrency trade have been frozen by Singapore’s regional banks

The Association of Cryptocurrency Enterprises and Startups in Singapore or ACCESS, requests the government to intervene with such actions. Anson Zeall, the chairperson of ACCESS, confirmed that 10 other similar companies are experiencing the same issue. All in all, the member count of ACCESS reaches up to 106 members. Zeall proceeded to explain that the occurrence seems to be common among FinTech hubs, stating that if bank accounts are truly being frozen due to association with cryptocurrencies, the Singaporean government must step in and resolve the conflict

These types of problems seem to be common among cryptocurrency traders and investors. A few examples would include when Bitfinex (Taiwan-based) and OKCoin (Hong Kong-based) had to halt transactions due to security concerns

Singapore’s central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), seems to be on the regional banks’ side. The MAS has released a statement which expresses that it has no intention to intervene with the banks who have decided the closure of the accounts.

Although names and figures weren’t publicly released, the president of the Singapore FinTech Association (SFA) Chai Hock Lai claims that numerous of its members’ bank accounts were also frozen. As of date, SFA is reported to have 185 members in total, with some attaining a dual type of membership with ACCESS

In the case of the Southeast Asian Bank DBS Group Holdings Ltd and Coinhako (a type of virtual wallet where cryptocurrencies can be stored and exchanged), the line is quite clearly drawn. Without providing any valid reason, all of the bank accounts belonging to CoinHako were closed. It has been officially reported that CoinHako can neither withdraw nor deposit currencies using Singaporean dollars

The co-founder of CoinHako, Yusho Liu stated that the guidelines released by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) served as the catalyst for the closure of most, if not all, the accounts associated with cryptocurrency

DBS released a statement which says that the decision to close or freeze accounts is mainly due to the violation of one of the four following rules:

  1. Constant maintenance of the bank account in good standing
  2. Ability to provide accurate and timely information.
  3. Lack of inexplicable inconsistencies in account behaviour
  4. Guarantee of lack of criminal or terrorist behaviour

Amidst these issues, Singapore continues to accept blockchain as an emerging form of technology. The MAS has also expressed its support to FinTech, as it has organized an event in celebration of FinTech. Furthermore, MAS is also known to be experimenting with the distributed ledger technology, taking part in cross-border trades and exchanges

MAS assured that it will remain committed to improve quality of the financial centre and Fintech hubs located within Singapore. In order to achieve this, MAS says that they (MAS and Fintech hubs) must come to an agreement wherein the risks of fraud and money laundering are effectively decreased.
